attributes.comment:
Dear Sir or Madam :

The proposal thoroughly explains why the fee raises are required. While I
sincerely appreciate the fine work done by the USCIS in an important issue like
immigration, I am also of the view that a 66% raise is unjustified. Immigrants
come to the US for freedom and expression of their skills. The cost of a H1B is
already around $2500 and a cost of securing a Green card almost double that.
Though the USCIS fee in the latter is not a big component, it will become one if
the fee raise is implemented. A skilled immigrant worker is contributing to the
economy by paying taxes and by bridging the shortage of skills. Most H1B
applicants return to their home country after their term but leave all the
Soc-Sec, Medicare contributions unclaimed. It should also be noted that skilled
non-immigrants often are young and single falling in to the 30% tax bracket.
Their tax contribution is significant.

The country needs to attract skilled labor force. The proposed fee raise will
prove a dampener and companies will feel more and more discouraged to hire
foreign labor. A foreign employee will also feel guilty that he costs more to
the company than a US citizen. Both factors are not healthy in a competitive and
a globalized world. While all other fee raises are palatable, the I-485 raise
from $325 to over $900 is too much. These significant fee raises will be the
"last straw in the camel's back" for an immigrant after waiting five or six
years for his green card! By the time the skilled immigrant has reached the
I-485 stage, he or she would have contributed over $100,000 in income taxes
alone, leave aside the economic, demographic and skill contributions.

The DOL is now clamoring to impose a PERM fee for labor certifications. The
drastic USCIS fee raise will only compound to the problems of potential
immigrants who are already in trauma due to long wait periods, employer's
business changes, problems in uniting their families etc. The United States is a
great country on the planet and its greatness stems from the equal opportunity
it provides for everyone who knocks her doors. So I request the Director to
kindly look at the problem in an integral way from all standpoints and implement
a fair, reasonable and phased increase in filing fees.
